misconfigurations.scenario: AWS account root user does not have MFA enabled or enforced
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Root account has no MFA device registered or root account accessed without MFA challenge
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable hardware MFA (U2F security key) for root account and implement mandatory MFA enforcement policy
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: As announced at re:Inforce 2025, AWS now enforces MFA for root users across all account types. The root account has unrestricted access to all resources. Without MFA, a compromised password grants complete account control. Hardware MFA (U2F security keys) provides stronger protection than virtual MFA apps. Root account credentials should be stored in a physical safe and only used for account recovery.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: Mandatory MFA enforcement for root users announced

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon ElastiCache Reserved Node Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of ElastiCache Reserved Nodes can help reduce costs
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase ElastiCache Reserved Nodes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of ElastiCache and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Nodes to help reduce costs incurred from using ElastiCache On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Node to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon GuardDuty threat detection is not enabled in all regions
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: GuardDuty is disabled in one or more AWS regions with no threat detection monitoring active
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable GuardDuty in all AWS regions and configure centralized log aggregation using AWS Organizations
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Amazon GuardDuty provides intelligent threat detection by continuously monitoring AWS accounts for malicious activities using machine learning. Without GuardDuty enabled, threats like unauthorized access, compromised credentials, and cryptocurrency mining go undetected. GuardDuty monitors CloudTrail events, VPC Flow Logs, and DNS logs to identify suspicious behavior patterns.
misconfigurations.notes: Announced at AWS re:Inforce 2025 with enhanced EKS runtime monitoring capabilities

misconfigurations.scenario: Idle Load Balancers
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A load balancer has had less than 100 requests per day for the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: consider deleting your load balancer.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Elastic Load Balancing configuration for load balancers that are not actively used. Any load balancer that is configured accrues charges. If a load balancer has no associated back-end instances or if network traffic is severely limited, the load balancer is not being used effectively

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Elasticsearch Reserved Instance Optimization

misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase Elasticsearch Reserved Instances.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of Elasticsearch and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Instances to help reduce costs incurred from using Elasticsearch On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Instance to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Unassociated Elastic IP Addresses
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An allocated Elastic IP address (EIP) is not associated with a running Amazon EC2 instance.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Associate the EIP with a running active instance, or release the unassociated EIP.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Elastic IP addresses (EIPs) that are not associated with a running Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instance. EIPs are static IP addresses designed for dynamic cloud computing. Unlike traditional static IP addresses, EIPs can mask the failure of an instance or Availability Zone by remapping a public IP address to another instance in your account. A nominal charge is imposed for an EIP that is not associated with a running instance.

misconfigurations.alert_criteria: predictable usage data can be used to justify a savings plan recommendation
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Savings Plans are a flexible pricing model that offer low prices on EC2, Fargate and Lambda usage, in exchange for a commitment to a consistent amount of usage (measured in $/hour) for a 1 or 3 year term. Savings Plans provide you the flexibility to use the compute option that best suits your needs and automatically save money, all without having to perform exchanges or modifications. When you sign up for a Savings Plan, you will be charged the discounted Savings Plans price for your usage up to your commitment.

misconfigurations.scenario: customer needs a database but is not sure which one to select or what to configure
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Heavy writes / simple queries = NoSQL

misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: read-heavy, write-heavy, or balanced workload? How many reads and writes are you going to need to per second? How will these values change if the numbers of users increases? How much data will you need to store? For how long? How quickly will this grow? Is there an upper limit in the near future? What are the sizes of each object? How will these objects be accessed? What are your requirements in terms of durability of data? Is this data store your source of truth? What are your latency requirements? How many concurrent users do you need to support? What is your data model and how are you going to query the data? Etc.

misconfigurations.scenario: Application credentials and API keys are hardcoded instead of using AWS Secrets Manager
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Secrets are stored in environment variables, configuration files, or hardcoded in application code
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Migrate all secrets to AWS Secrets Manager with automatic rotation enabled and KMS encryption
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Hardcoded secrets in code, configuration files, or container images are a critical security vulnerability. AWS Secrets Manager provides encrypted storage with automatic rotation capabilities and audit trails. Secrets Manager integrates with RDS, Redshift, DocumentDB, and other services for automatic credential rotation, eliminating the need to update application code when rotating secrets.
misconfigurations.notes: Secrets Manager provides automatic rotation for supported AWS services

metadata.source: AWS Security Best Practices 2025 / Community Contribution

misconfigurations.scenario: Public-facing applications do not have AWS WAF protection enabled
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Application Load Balancer, API Gateway, or CloudFront distribution has no WAF association and no protection against OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS WAF with managed rule groups for OWASP protection, IP rate limiting, and geo-blocking
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS WAF protects web applications from common exploits like SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and DDoS attacks. Without WAF, applications are vulnerable to automated attacks and zero-day exploits. AWS Managed Rules provide continuously updated protection against emerging threats. WAF can be deployed on CloudFront, ALB, API Gateway, and AppSync.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Managed Rules provide protection against OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities

metadata.source: AWS Security Best Practices 2025 / Community Contribution

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure that only necessary / needed snapshots are available for use
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: if snapshot is older than seven days and/or is older than another snapshot made from an identical volume, then recommend deletion
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete snapshot

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure ebs volumes are deleted when an instance is terminated
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: "delete on termination" flag on instances is set to false
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: set "delete on termination" flag to true (enable automatic deletion upon instance termination)

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EBS Provisioned IOPS (SSD) Volume Attachment Configuration
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An Amazon EC2 instance that can be EBS-optimized has an attached Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volume but the instance is not EBS-optimized.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: create new "ebs-optimized" ssd by provisioning a new instance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes that are attached to an Amazon EBS-optimizable Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instance that is not EBS-optimized. Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes in the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) are designed to deliver the expected performance only when they are attached to an EBS-optimized instance.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to prevent volumes (root or attached) from filling up, forcing a restart and leading to a new IP address (if an elastic ip has not been assigned)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: volume storage capacity has less than threshold (%) remaining
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: increase the storage size of your targeted volumes

misconfigurations.scenario: Overutilized Amazon EBS Magnetic Volumes
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An Amazon EBS Magnetic volume is attached to an instance that can be EBS-optimized or is part of a cluster compute network with a daily median of more than 95 IOPS, and varies by less than 10% of the median value for at least 7 of the past 14 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action:
- For consistently higher IOPS, you can use a Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volume. 
- For bursty IOPS, you can use a General Purpose (SSD) volume
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) Magnetic volumes that are potentially overutilized and might benefit from a more efficient configuration. A Magnetic volume is designed for applications with moderate or bursty I/O requirements, and the IOPS rate is not guaranteed. It delivers approximately 100 IOPS on average, with a best-effort ability to burst to hundreds of IOPS. For consistently higher IOPS, you can use a Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volume. For bursty IOPS, you can use a General Purpose (SSD) volume. To get daily utilization metrics, download the report for this check. The detailed report shows a column for each of the last 14 days. If there is no active EBS volume, the cell is empty. If there is  insufficient data to make a reliable measurement, the cell contains "N/A". If there is sufficient data, the cell contains the daily median and the percentage of the variance in relation to the median (for example, "256 / 20%").

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Security Hub is not enabled to aggregate security findings
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Security Hub is not enabled and no centralized security posture management exists
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Security Hub to aggregate findings from GuardDuty, Inspector, Macie, and third-party security tools into a unified dashboard
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Security Hub aggregates security findings from multiple AWS services and third-party tools, providing a comprehensive view of your security posture. Without Security Hub, security teams must manually check multiple services, leading to missed vulnerabilities and delayed incident response. Security Hub includes automated compliance checks against standards like CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark, PCI-DSS, and AWS Best Practices.
misconfigurations.notes: Enhanced at re:Inforce 2025 with improved threat signal analysis

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Config is not enabled to track resource configuration changes and compliance
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: AWS Config is disabled with no configuration history tracking and compliance violations going undetected
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Config with managed rules for CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark and organizational security policies
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Config continuously monitors and records AWS resource configurations, enabling compliance auditing, security analysis, and change tracking. Without Config, unauthorized changes go unnoticed and compliance violations remain undetected. Config integrates with Security Hub to provide compliance status against multiple standards and can automatically remediate non-compliant resources using Systems Manager.
misconfigurations.notes: Config integrates with Security Hub for compliance reporting and Systems Manager for auto-remediation

metadata.source: AWS Security Best Practices 2025 / Community Contribution

misconfigurations.scenario: Mission-critical applications lack AWS Shield Advanced DDoS protection
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: CloudFront distributions or ELBs handling critical traffic without Shield Advanced and no DDoS cost protection or 24/7 response team access
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Shield Advanced for critical resources and configure DDoS Response Team (DRT) access for 24/7 support during attacks
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Shield Standard provides basic DDoS protection, but Shield Advanced offers application-layer protection, cost protection against DDoS-related charges, and 24/7 access to the AWS DDoS Response Team. Critical applications handling financial transactions, healthcare data, or serving millions of users should use Shield Advanced to ensure availability during sophisticated DDoS attacks.
misconfigurations.notes: Shield Advanced includes cost protection and access to AWS DDoS Response Team

metadata.source: AWS Security Best Practices 2025 / Community Contribution

misconfigurations.alert_criteria: ecs task definition set to inactive status
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete or update task

misconfigurations.alert_criteria: if max memory utilization is > 50% for more than 3 concecutive time periods AND autoscaling is not enabled
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: enable autoscalling policy with target tracking; set target to 50%

misconfigurations.alert_criteria: platform version != LATEST
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: update service in console to LATEST
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: this will cause the service to automatically rollback to the last stable state

misconfigurations.scenario:
- user wants to increase the reliability of their ecs sevices / tasks and/or
- user has been experiencing frequent service failures and/or
- users' ecs services have been failing health checks
misconfigurations.alert_criteria:
- fargate launch type and/or
- tasks have transitioned to a failed state > 3 times in the last 21 day and/or 
- are failing healthchecks
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: enable deployment rollback / circut breaker
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: this will cause the service to automatically rollback to the last stable state

misconfigurations.scenario: ECS task definitions are configured with unsafe defaults including public IPs, privileged mode, or plaintext secrets
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: ECS tasks assigned public IP addresses when not required, containers running in privileged mode, or secrets passed as plaintext environment variables
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Configure ECS tasks without public IPs in private subnets, disable privileged mode, use Secrets Manager for credentials, and enable read-only root filesystems
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: ECS task misconfigurations create significant security risks. Public IP assignments expose containers directly to the internet. Privileged mode grants containers host-level access. Plaintext secrets in environment variables can be extracted by anyone with task describe permissions. Security Hub includes checks for these misconfigurations and AWS recommends using private subnets with NAT gateways, non-privileged containers, and Secrets Manager integration.
misconfigurations.notes: Security Hub provides automated checks for ECS task definition misconfigurations

metadata.source: AWS Security Best Practices 2025 / Community Contribution

misconfigurations.scenario: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) templates are not scanned for security vulnerabilities before deployment
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: CloudFormation, Terraform, or CDK templates not scanned and CI/CD pipeline lacks IaC security scanning
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable Amazon Inspector Code Security in CI/CD pipelines to scan IaC templates, application code (SAST), and dependencies (SCA) before production deployment
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Amazon Inspector Code Security (GA at re:Inforce 2025) provides shift left security by scanning Infrastructure as Code templates, application source code (SAST), and open-source dependencies (SCA). This identifies misconfigurations, vulnerabilities, and security issues before they reach production. Inspector integrates with CodePipeline, GitHub Actions, and GitLab CI to automatically scan pull requests.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: Amazon Inspector Code Security now Generally Available

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EC2 Reserved Instance Lease Expiration
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: The Reserved Instance lease expires in less than 30 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider purchasing a new Reserved Instance to replace the one that is nearing the end of its term. For more information
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon EC2 Reserved Instances that are scheduled to expire within the next 30 days or have expired in the preceding 30 days. Reserved Instances do not renew automatically; you can continue using an EC2 instance covered by the reservation without interruption, but you will be charged On-Demand rates. New Reserved Instances can have the same parameters as the expired ones, or you can purchase Reserved Instances with different parameters. The estimated monthly savings we show is the difference between the On-Demand and Reserved Instance rates for the same instance type.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has unencrypted volumes currently in use
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: volumes (attached or not) are currently unencrypted
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: encrypt (or delete) volumes

misconfigurations.scenario: user has unattached or unused volumes
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: volumes are not attached to instances and have little to no activity
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete volumes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume configurations and warns when volumes appear to be underused. Charges begin when a volume is created. If a volume remains unattached or has very low write activity (excluding boot volumes) for a period of time, the volume is probably not being used.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has instances that are not being used regularly
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: cpu utilization of instances is below threshold
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: stop or terminate instance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: tagging strategies could also be recommended to improve the general "intelligence" of the recommendations; Checks the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances that were running at any time during the last 14 days and alerts you if the daily CPU utilization was 10% or less and network I/O was 5 MB or less on 4 or more days. Running instances generate hourly usage charges. Although some scenarios can result in low utilization by design, you can often lower your costs by managing the number and size of your instances.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has already reduced waste, has an okay understanding of their future compute usage requirements, and wants to save money on their instance usage rates going forward
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: boto recommends "ec2 level savings plans" and the user has already gone through a "waste reduction" process"
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: purchase general savings plan
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: make sure to prompt the user, ensuring they have already maximized their savings by reducing waste, before recommending a savings plan: Checks your usage of EC2, Fargate, and Lambda over the last 30 days and provides Savings Plan purchase recommendations, which allows you to commit to a consistent usage amount measured in $/hour for a one or three year term in exchange for discounted rates. These are sourced from AWS Cost Explorer which can be used to get more detailed recommendation information, or to purchase a savings plan. These recommendations should be considered an alternative to your RI recommendations and choosing to act fully on both sets of recommendations would likely lead to over commitment.

- tag(s) denote the instance as a "workday" instance and/or

misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: ec2s are only used during specified hours; usually during regular business hours or when attached to a job

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EC2 to EBS Throughput Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Compare the maximum throughput of your EBS volumes (see Amazon EBS Volume Types) with the maximum throughput of the EC2 instance they are attached to (see Instance Types That Support EBS Optimization). Consider attaching your volumes to an instance that supports higher throughput to EBS for optimal performance.; In the preceding day (UTC), the aggregate throughput (megabytes/sec) of the EBS volumes attached to the EC2 instance exceeded 95% of the published throughput between the instance and the EBS volumes more than 50% of time.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Compare the maximum throughput of your EBS volumes (see Amazon EBS Volume Types) with the maximum throughput of the EC2 instance they are attached to (see Instance Types That Support EBS Optimization). Consider attaching your volumes to an instance that supports higher throughput to EBS for optimal performance.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon EBS volumes whose performance might be affected by the maximum throughput capability of the Amazon EC2 instance they are attached to. To optimize performance, you should ensure that the maximum throughput of an EC2 instance is greater than the aggregate maximum throughput of the attached EBS volumes. This check computes the total EBS volume throughput for each five-minute period in the preceding day (UTC) for each EBS-optimized instance and alerts you if usage in more than half of those periods was greater than 95% of the maximum throughput of the EC2 instance

misconfigurations.scenario: Idle Amazon EC2 Instance
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An instance had less than 5% daily average CPU utilization and 5 MB or less network I/O on at least 4 of the previous 14 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: stop or terminate instance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances that were running at any time during the last 14 days and alerts you if the daily CPU utilization was 5% or less and network I/O was 5 MB or less on 4 or more days. Running instances generate hourly usage charges. Although some scenarios can result in low utilization by design, you can often lower your costs by managing the number and size of your instances.

misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce the number of rules in a security group by deleting unnecessary or overlapping rules
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks each Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) security group for an excessive number of rules. If a security group has a large number of rules, performance can be degraded

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to increase the security of their ec2 instances

misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce the number of rules in a security group by deleting unnecessary or overlapping rules
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks each Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) security group for an excessive number of rules. If a security group has a large number of rules, performance can be degraded

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to increase the security of their ec2 instances
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An Amazon EC2-VPC instance has more than 50 security group rules.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce the number of rules associated with an instance by deleting unnecessary or overlapping rules
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances that have a large number of security group rules. Performance can be degraded if an instance has a large number of rules.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to increase the security of their ec2 instances
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An Amazon EC2-Classic instance has more than 100 security group rules.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce the number of rules associated with an instance by deleting unnecessary or overlapping rules
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances that have a large number of security group rules. Performance can be degraded if an instance has a large number of rules.

misconfigurations.scenario: High Utilization Amazon EC2 Instances
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An instance had more than 90% daily average CPU utilization on at least 4 of the previous 14 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action:
- add more instanes OR increase instance size
- add ALB to application
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances that were running at any time during the last 14 days and alerts you if the daily CPU utilization was more than 90% on 4 or more days. Consistent high utilization can indicate optimized, steady performance, but it can also indicate that an application does not have enough resources. To get daily CPU utilization data, download the report for this check

misconfigurations.scenario: users wants to automatically manage data storage tiers
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: s3 lifecycle manager is turned off; intelligent tiering is not enabled
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: turn on lifecycle manager

misconfigurations.alert_criteria: s3 object is not encrypted
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: encrypt object
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: we recommend encrypting objects if you are concerned about [risk reason 1, risk reason 2, risk reason... n]

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to be made aware of the locations of all public s3 buckets (or their contents)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: bucket or its subfolders are open to the public
misconfigurations.recommendation_action:
- Randomise your bucket names! There is no need to use company-backup.s3.amazonaws.com.
- Set appropriate permissions and audit regularly.  
- If possible create two buckets - one for your public assets and another for private data.
- Try Amazon Macie - it can automatically classify and secure sensitive data.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to make sure all environments are healthy
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: environment != healthy
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: see logs to address issue or delete environment
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: see documentation for alert message details

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to make sure all environments are up to date
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: platform state == deprecated
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: update your environment

misconfigurations.scenario: pods OR nodes within cluster are not appropriately sized (artur to clarify)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: workloads (cpu, memory, network IOPs, etc.) for the previous 14, 30, 90 days, multiplied by 1.4 are too large...
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: recommend the proper size for each pod

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EKS clusters do not have GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection enabled
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: GuardDuty EKS Runtime Monitoring is not enabled with no threat detection for containerized workloads
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection for EKS to monitor container runtime behavior and detect threats in Kubernetes environments
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Announced at re:Inforce 2025, GuardDuty now provides runtime threat detection for EKS clusters. This monitors container behavior, Kubernetes API calls, and pod-level network activity to detect threats like cryptocurrency mining, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Without this protection, compromised containers can operate undetected.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS re:Inforce 2025: GuardDuty Extended Threat Detection for EKS announced

misconfigurations.scenario: EMR (or other) cluster is used and task nodes are not utilizing spot instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: use spot instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: useful for high CPU but low Memory requirements; i.e. high processing requirement but low (or no) caching required

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) Reserved Instance Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of RDS Reserved Instances can help reduce costs.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase RDS Reserved Instances.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of RDS and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Instances to help reduce costs incurred from using RDS On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Instance to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon RDS Idle DB Instances
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An active DB instance has not had a connection in the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider taking a snapshot of the idle DB instance and then either stopping it or deleting it. Stopping the DB instance removes some of the costs for it, but does not remove storage costs. A stopped instance keeps all automated backups based upon the configured retention period. Stopping a DB instance usually incurs additional costs when compared to deleting the instance and then retaining only the final snapshot
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the configuration of your Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS) for any DB instances that appear to be idle. If a DB instance has not had a connection for a prolonged period of time, you can delete the instance to reduce costs. If persistent storage is needed for data on the instance, you can use lower-cost options such as taking and retaining a DB snapshot. Manually created DB snapshots are retained until you delete them. Data for Amazon RDS instances created in the Asia Pacific (Seoul) region (sa-east-1) is not available. We are working to fix this issue as soon as possible

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Route 53 Alias Resource Record Sets
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A resource record set is a CNAME to an Amazon S3 website.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Replace the listed CNAME resource record sets with alias resource record sets; You also need to change the record type from CNAME to A or AAAA, depending on the AWS resource
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for resource record sets that can be changed to alias resource record sets to improve performance and save money. An alias resource record set routes DNS queries to an AWS resource (for example, an Elastic Load Balancing load balancer or an Amazon S3 bucket) or to another Route 53 resource record set. When you use alias resource record sets, Route 53 routes your DNS queries to AWS resources free of charge. Hosted zones created by AWS services wont appear in your check results.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Route 53 Latency Resource Record Sets
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: resources exist in multiple regions and only one latency resource record set is configured for a particular domain name.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: define a latency resource record set for each region
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon Route 53 latency record sets that are configured inefficiently. To allow Amazon Route 53 to route queries to the region with the lowest network latency, you should create latency resource record sets for a particular domain name (such as example.com) in different regions. If you create only one latency resource record set for a domain name, all queries are routed to one region, and you pay extra for latency-based routing without getting the benefits. Hosted zones created by AWS services wont appear in your check results.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Redshift Reserved Node Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of Redshift Reserved Nodes can help reduce costs.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase Redshift Reserved Nodes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of Redshift and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Nodes to help reduce costs incurred from using Redshift On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Nodes to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Underutilized Amazon Redshift Clusters
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A running cluster has not had a connection in the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot, or downsizing the cluster.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Amazon Redshift configuration for clusters that appear to be underutilized. If an Amazon Redshift cluster has not had a connection for a prolonged period of time or is using a low amount of CPU, you can use lower-cost options such as downsizing the cluster or shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot. Final snapshots are retained even after you delete your cluster.
misconfigurations.notes: can beat our aws recommendations by determining which path is the correct path, and, if resizing is optimal, to which size

misconfigurations.scenario: time between when the last record in a batch was written to a stream (e.g., Kinesis, DynamoDB) and when Lambda received the batch increases dramatically
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed:
There are a few scenarios that could increase the iterator age:
    a high execution duration for a function
    not enough shards in a stream
    invocation errors
    insufficient batch size

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Lambda Functions with Excessive Timeouts
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Functions where > 10% of invocations end in an error due to a timeout on any given day within the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: increase the timeout setting for the function.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Lambda functions with high timeout rates that may result in high cost. Lambda charges based on execution time for your function and number of requests for your function. Function timeouts result in function errors that may cause retries that incur additional request and execution time charges. For more information, see Monitoring and troubleshooting Lambda applications.

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Lambda Functions with High Error Rates
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Functions where > 10% of invocations end in error on any given day within the last 7 days
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider the following guidelines to reduce errors. Function errors include errors returned by the function's code and errors returned by the function's runtime. To help you troubleshoot Lambda errors, Lambda integrates with services like Amazon CloudWatch and AWS X-Ray. You can use a combination of logs, metrics, alarms, and X-ray tracing to quickly detect and identify issues in your function code, API, or other resources that support your application.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Lambda functions with high error rates that may result in high cost. Lambda charges based on the number of requests and aggregate execution time for your function. Function errors may cause retries that incur additional charges. Consider the following guidelines to reduce errors. Function errors include errors returned by the function's code and errors returned by the function's runtime. To help you troubleshoot Lambda errors, Lambda integrates with services like Amazon CloudWatch and AWS X-Ray. You can use a combination of logs, metrics, alarms, and X-ray tracing to quickly detect and identify issues in your function code, API, or other resources that support your application.

misconfigurations.scenario: CloudFront Header Forwarding and Cache Hit Ratio
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: One or more request headers that CloudFront forwards to your origin might significantly reduce your cache hit ratio.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider whether the request headers provide enough benefit to justify the negative effect on the cache hit ratio. If your origin returns the same object regardless of the value of a given header, we recommend that you don't configure CloudFront to forward that header to the origin.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the HTTP request headers that CloudFront currently receives from the client and forwards to your origin server. Some headers, such as Date or User-Agent, significantly reduce the cache hit ratio (the proportion of requests that are served from a CloudFront edge cache). This increases the load on your origin and reduces performance because CloudFront must forward more requests to your origin

misconfigurations.scenario: CloudFront Alternate Domain Names
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Yellow: A CloudFront distribution includes alternate domain names, but the DNS configuration is not correctly set up with a CNAME record or an Amazon Route 53 alias resource record.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Update the DNS configuration to route DNS queries to the CloudFront distribution
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed:
Checks Amazon CloudFront distributions for alternate domain names (CNAMES) that have incorrectly configured DNS settings. If a CloudFront distribution includes alternate domain names, the DNS configuration for the domains must route DNS queries to that distribution.

Note: This check assumes Amazon Route 53 DNS and Amazon CloudFront distribution are configured in the same AWS account. As such the Alert list may include resources otherwise working as expected due to DNS setting outsides of this AWS account.

misconfigurations.scenario: CloudFront Content Delivery Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: The amount of data transferred out of the bucket to your users by GET requests in the 30 days preceding the check is at least 25 times greater than the average amount of data stored in the bucket.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider using CloudFront for better performance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for cases where data transfer from Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) buckets could be accelerated by using Amazon CloudFront, the AWS global content delivery service. When you configure CloudFront to deliver your content, requests for your content are automatically routed to the nearest edge location where content is cached, so it can be delivered to your users with the best possible performance. A high ratio of data transferred out to the data stored in the bucket indicates that you could benefit from using Amazon CloudFront to deliver the data. To estimate the retrieval activity of users, only data transferred by using a GET request is counted for this check. In addition, the transfer activity from the last 24 hours is not included.

misconfigurations.scenario: CloudFront Content Delivery Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: The amount of data transferred out of the bucket to your users by GET requests in the 30 days preceding the check is at least 10 TB and at least 25 times greater than the average amount of data stored in the bucket.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: If the data transferred is 10 TB per month or more, see Amazon CloudFront Pricing to explore possible cost savings.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for cases where data transfer from Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) buckets could be accelerated by using Amazon CloudFront, the AWS global content delivery service. When you configure CloudFront to deliver your content, requests for your content are automatically routed to the nearest edge location where content is cached, so it can be delivered to your users with the best possible performance. A high ratio of data transferred out to the data stored in the bucket indicates that you could benefit from using Amazon CloudFront to deliver the data. To estimate the retrieval activity of users, only data transferred by using a GET request is counted for this check. In addition, the transfer activity from the last 24 hours is not included.

Checks Amazon CloudFront distributions for alternate domain names (CNAMES) that have incorrectly configured DNS settings. If a CloudFront distribution includes alternate domain names, the DNS configuration for the domains must route DNS queries to that distribution.

Note: This check assumes Amazon Route 53 DNS and Amazon CloudFront distribution are configured in the same AWS account. As such the Alert list may include resources otherwise working as expected due to DNS setting outsides of this AWS account.
